The exponential form

Since \(z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )\) and since \(e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\) we therefore obtain another way in which to denote a complex number: \(z=re^{i\theta}\), called the exponential form.


Key Point

The exponential form of a complex number is \[z = re^{i\theta}\quad\text{in which}\quad r=|z|\quad\text{and}\quad\theta=\text{arg}(z)\] so \[z=re^{i\theta}=r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)\]
